sols_html:
To evaluate the slope of the curve at \(x = 0\), we let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \int_{0}^{2\sin(x)}e^{-t^{2}}\,dt\end{aligned}\]

and evaluate \(f'(0)\). By the fundamental theorem of calculus, we know that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \int_{0}^{2\sin(x)}e^{-t^{2}}\,dt = F(2\sin(x)) - F(0)\end{aligned}\]

where \(F\) is the antiderivative of the integrand (i.e

\[\begin{aligned} F'(t) = e^{-t^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

). Taking the derivative with respect to \(x\), we find

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx}\left[F(2\sin(x)) - F(0) \right] \\ &= F'(2\sin(x))\cdot\frac{d}{dx}(2\sin(x)) \\ &= e^{-4\sin^{2}(x)}\cdot2\cos(x) \\ f'(0) &= 2\end{aligned}\]

So the slope of the curve \(y = f(x)\) at \(x = 0\) is 2.
